text: How does collecting more experimental data help you predict the likelihood of each possible outcome occurring? How does proportional reasoning help you make predictions?

Experimental probability is found by finding the ratio of (Number of desired outcomes)/(Total number of outcomes)

Doing just a few experiments may not get you a pattern of what is likely to happen with an event (e.g., when Kaleb made a prediction from doing just two tosses of the cup). You need many experiments to see what is likely to happen (e.g., when we collected the class data to see that matches and no matches were equally likely),

You can use proportional reasoning to scale up or down the experimental probability to make predictions about what will happen with other trials.
